headline: Trade deals in focus amid stock market rebound: What to know this week
description: A quiet week of economic data is set to greet a rallying stock market, keeping investor focus on the latest updates in Trump's trade war.
summary: Renewed investor optimism surrounding potential US trade deals, particularly with China, propelled stocks to multi-month highs last week, recovering losses from earlier tariff-driven sell-offs. While strategists are cautiously optimistic, they acknowledge that uncertainties remain due to the lack of cemented agreements and lingering policy concerns. The market is now anticipating fewer interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year.

headline: U.S. lawmakers have concerns about Apple-Alibaba deal
description: The Trump administration and congressional officials are scrutinizing a deal between Apple and Alibaba that would bring Alibaba-powered AI features to iPhones sold in China, according to The New York Times. Citing anonymous sources, the NYT says White House officials and members of the House Select Committee on China have asked Apple executives directly about the deal, with questions focused on what data would be shared with Alibaba and whether the company was making any commitments to Chinese r
summary: US officials are investigating a potential deal between Apple and Alibaba to bring AI features to iPhones in China, focusing on data sharing and commitments to Chinese regulators. Lawmakers have expressed concerns about Alibaba's ties to the Chinese Communist Party and Apple's lack of transparency regarding the agreement. The deal, publicly acknowledged only by Alibaba, raises concerns amid rising US-China tensions and potential tariffs affecting Apple's business.

headline: Silicon Valley's conference season kicks off amid AI, tariff trepidation
description: Big Tech is gearing up for its annual conference season, with AI and chips top of mind.
summary: The tech industry's conference season is kicking off with major events from Google, Microsoft, Apple, and chip manufacturers, where they'll showcase AI advancements and future products. These companies aim to address investor concerns about issues like Trump's tariffs, AI growth fears, and chip export restrictions while demonstrating a positive outlook. Specifically, Microsoft and Google will focus on updates to their AI models and cloud platforms, aiming to reassure Wall Street about their AI investments and growth strategies.

headline: Nvidia announces humanoid robotics, customer AI infrastructure offerings at Computex 2025
description: Nvidia debuted a host of new AI-based technologies at Computex 2025.
summary: Nvidia unveiled a range of new AI technologies at Computex, including advancements in humanoid robotics with Isaac GR00T-Dreams and more flexible AI server configurations through NVLink Fusion and RTX Pro Blackwell servers.  These announcements capitalize on relaxed AI export restrictions and a major deal to supply AI processors to Saudi Arabia, further solidifying Nvidia's push into the burgeoning physical AI and cloud computing sectors. The company is also launching DGX Cloud Lepton to give customers access to cloud-based AI processing.

headline: Trade deals in focus amid stock market rebound: What to know this week
description: A quiet week of economic data is set to greet a rallying stock market, keeping investor focus on the latest updates in Trump's trade war.
summary: Investor confidence fueled by positive developments in US trade deals drove significant stock market gains last week, with major indexes recovering previous losses. While tariff headlines remain a key focus, uncertainty persists as actual trade agreements are still being negotiated. Markets are also adjusting expectations for Federal Reserve interest rate cuts amid the improved economic outlook.

headline: Silicon Valley's conference season kicks off amid AI, tariff trepidation
description: Big Tech is gearing up for its annual conference season, with AI and chips top of mind.
summary: The tech industry's conference season is kicking off with events from Google, Microsoft, Apple, and major chip manufacturers, where they will showcase their latest AI advancements and product roadmaps. These companies aim to address investor anxieties surrounding issues like AI growth fears and trade restrictions while demonstrating positive future prospects. Microsoft and Google, in particular, will focus on integrating AI into their cloud platforms and enterprise services.

headline: This 1 Catalyst Could Send Bitcoin Skyrocketing Higher, According to Silicon Valley Billionaire Tim Draper
description: Publicly traded corporations could be the next big buyers of Bitcoin.  MicroStrategy pioneered the idea of buying Bitcoin, and now other companies are starting to follow its example.  According to Silicon Valley venture capitalist Tim Draper, corporations have a responsibility to buy Bitcoin to maximize shareholder value.
summary: The article discusses the growing argument, championed by figures like Tim Draper, that corporations should buy Bitcoin to maximize shareholder value, following MicroStrategy's lead. While such corporate adoption could significantly increase Bitcoin's price, the article cautions about the risks of holding a volatile asset like Bitcoin on a balance sheet, referencing Tesla's past experience as a cautionary tale. The Motley Fool suggests exploring other investment opportunities.

headline: Stock market today: S&P 500 notches 6-day win streak, Dow, Nasdaq rise as Wall Street shakes off Moody's downgrade
description: Moody's downgrade of the US credit rating is shaking Wall Street as the deficit balloons.
summary: US stocks edged higher despite Moody's downgrading the US credit rating, as bond yields eased and investors monitored developments regarding Trump's tariffs. The market is also focusing on upcoming retail earnings reports from companies like Target and Home Depot, and light economic announcements. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent warned countries that their imports will return to facing "Liberation Day" hikes if they don't negotiate deals "in good faith" during the 90-day pause.

headline: Judge pressures Apple to approve Fortnite or return to court
description: A federal judge is asking Apple to approve Fortnite's submission on the U.S. App Store or return to court to explain the legal basis as to why it has not done so. In a new filing, U.S. District Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers confirms the court has received Epic Games' latest motion, where it demands that Apple approve Fortnite for distribution on the App Store. The clearly annoyed judge asks Apple to show the court the "legal authority upon which Apple contends that it can ignore this Court's orde
summary: A federal judge is demanding Apple either approve Fortnite's return to the U.S. App Store following a court injunction or explain its legal justification for refusing to do so. The judge appears frustrated with Apple's delay and is considering further action, potentially including contempt charges, if the company doesn't comply with the court's order. This stems from Epic Games resubmitting Fortnite after winning the right to include external payment links, which Apple is delaying until its appeal is resolved.

headline: Microsoft goes all in on AI agents at annual Build conference
description: Microsoft is leaning into AI agents at its annual Build conference in Seattle.
summary: Microsoft envisions a future dominated by AI agents capable of performing diverse tasks for individuals and organizations, highlighting their "open agentic web" concept at the Build conference. The company is providing tools like Copilot Studio and the Microsoft 365 Agents Toolkit to empower businesses to develop custom AI agents, expecting widespread adoption and significant business impact. Microsoft is also developing multi-agent systems where AI agents can communicate with each other and perform multiple tasks.

headline: Stock market today: S&P 500 notches 6-day win streak, Dow, Nasdaq rise as Wall Street shakes off Moody's downgrade
description: Moody's downgrade of the US credit rating is shaking Wall Street as the deficit balloons.
summary: US stocks edged higher Monday despite Moody's downgrade of the US credit rating and ongoing concerns about President Trump's tariff policies. Bond yields eased from session highs as investors focused on upcoming retail earnings and manufacturing data, while digesting warnings from the Treasury Secretary regarding trade negotiations. Trump also publicly pressured Walmart to absorb tariff costs.

headline: Netflix stock downgraded on valuation concerns despite recent defensive strength
description: Netflix's high valuation is a key reason for the downgrade, according to JPMorgan.
summary: Netflix stock closed flat after JPMorgan downgraded it to Neutral, citing an elevated valuation following a significant price surge this year, despite raising the price target. The downgrade reflects concerns about the stock's risk/reward balance and potential investor rotation into other tech companies as macroeconomic concerns ease, even though Netflix's ad-supported tier shows strong growth potential.

headline: Netflix stock downgraded on valuation concerns despite recent defensive strength
description: Netflix's high valuation is a key reason for the downgrade, according to JPMorgan.
summary: Netflix stock remained flat after JPMorgan downgraded it to Neutral, citing valuation concerns following significant gains, despite simultaneously raising the price target. The analyst still holds a long-term bullish view but anticipates a potential rotation into other tech stocks as broader market concerns ease and as Netflix enters a seasonally slower quarter.  Despite the downgrade, Netflix's growing ad-supported tier and potential for increased advertising revenue remain key positive factors.

headline: Stock market today: S&P 500 snaps 6-day win streak; Dow, Nasdaq slide as tariff relief rally fades
description: US stocks struggled amid growing warnings that relief over trade developments could be short-lived.
summary: US stocks declined Tuesday, ending a recent rally, due to concerns that investor optimism regarding trade and inflation is premature. Downward pressure was amplified by Home Depot's mixed earnings and warnings from figures like Jamie Dimon about persistent tariff impacts and potentially delayed interest rate cuts. Uncertainty around trade and Trump's tax bill further contributed to the market's pullback.

headline: Google announces smart glasses partnerships as it takes on Meta, Apple preps its own eyewear
description: Google says its working with Warby Parker and Gentle Monster on AR smart glasses.
summary: Google is partnering with Warby Parker, Gentle Monster, and Samsung to develop AI-powered smart glasses, directly competing with Meta and potentially Apple in the emerging market. These glasses will run on Android XR, feature AI capabilities via Gemini, and offer functionalities like real-time translation and turn-by-turn directions, aiming for a more consumer-friendly approach than Google's previous Google Glass attempt. The company plans to work with partners and testers to refine the glasses, emphasizing both usefulness and privacy.

headline: Once worth over $1B, Microsoft-backed Builder.ai is running out of money
description: AI software company Builder.ai is entering insolvency proceedings, a company spokesperson confirmed to TechCrunch. The Microsoft-backed unicorn, which has raised more than $450 million in funding, rose to prominence for its AI-based platform that aimed to simplify the process of building apps and websites. According to the spokesperson, Builder.ai, also known as Engineer.ai Corporation, is appointing an administrator to "manage the company's affairs." "Despite the tireless efforts of our current
summary: AI software company Builder.ai, backed by Microsoft and once valued at over $1 billion, is entering insolvency proceedings due to past financial challenges and decisions. The company, known for its AI-based app development platform, is appointing an administrator to manage its affairs after facing leadership shakeups, revenue downgrades, and allegations of inflated sales figures. Builder.ai will focus on supporting employees and exploring options for parts of the business during this process.

headline: Nvidia says US export controls on AI chips to China were 'a failure'
description: TAIPEI (Reuters) -U.S. export controls on artificial intelligence chips to China were "a failure", Nvidia Chief Executive Jensen Huang said on Wednesday.  "All in all, the export control was a failure," Huang said adding, "The fundamental assumptions that led to the AI diffusion rule in the beginning, in the first place, has been proven to be fundamentally flawed."  The U.S. block on sales of advanced AI chips to China has forced companies there to buy semiconductors from Chinese designers such as Huawei, while also spurring China to invest aggressively to develop a supply chain that doesn't rely on manufacturers outside the country.
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang stated that U.S. export controls on AI chips to China have failed, leading Chinese companies to seek alternatives like Huawei and invest in domestic chip production. This has caused Nvidia's market share in China to plummet, and prompted China to criticize the U.S. measures as discriminatory and harmful to bilateral trade.

headline: Crypto scores a victory as GENIUS Act stablecoin legislation stays alive in Senate
description: A bill to regulate stablecoins passed a key procedural hurdle in the Senate Monday night, paving a path for final passage of legislation pushed by the crypto industry.
summary: A stablecoin regulation bill advanced in the Senate, aiming to establish reserve requirements and transparency for stablecoin issuers while banning algorithmic stablecoins. Despite opposition from some Democrats like Sen. Warren who raised concerns about consumer protections and potential conflicts of interest involving the Trump family's crypto ventures, enough bipartisan support exists to move the bill forward. The bill seeks to prevent future stablecoin collapses like that of Terra Luna in 2022.

headline: Google announces smart glasses partnerships as it takes on Meta, Apple preps its own eyewear
description: Google says its working with Warby Parker and Gentle Monster on AR smart glasses.
summary: Google is partnering with Warby Parker, Gentle Monster, and Samsung to develop AI-powered smart glasses, entering the market to compete with Meta and the anticipated smart glasses from Apple. These glasses will run on Android XR, feature AI capabilities from Gemini, and offer smartphone integration through features like a camera, speakers, and an optional in-lens display. This initiative marks Google's renewed effort in the smart glasses arena, aiming to improve upon past failures with updated technology and a focus on design and privacy.

headline: Nvidia CEO praises Trump move to scrap some AI export curbs
description: TAIPEI (Reuters) -U.S. export controls on artificial intelligence chips to China were "a failure" as they have cost American companies billions of dollars in lost sales, Nvidia Chief Executive Jensen Huang said on Wednesday.  Huang's comments were levelled at the Biden administration's AI diffusion rule that sought to curb exports of sophisticated AI chips by dividing the world into three tiers, with China blocked entirely.  The Trump administration has said it is going to modify the rules.
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang criticized U.S. export controls on AI chips to China, calling them a "failure" that cost American companies billions in lost sales and spurred China to develop its own domestic chip industry. Huang stated that the controls have backfired, leading to increased competition from Chinese firms and a significant reduction in Nvidia's market share in China. He also praised Trump's approach to AI and stated by reversing the prior restrictions, the president demonstrated he understands U.S. companies are not the only providers of such technology.

headline: Elon Musk recommits to lead Tesla: Overview of the robotaxi launch
description: Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk recommitted himself to the electric vehicle company for the next five years, he affirmed at Bloomberg’s Qatar Economic Forum. William Blair Group head of energy and sustainability research sector Jed Dorsheimer speaks more about Tesla's innovation, the rollout of its robotaxi beta starting in Austin, Texas, and the stock hit the EV manufacturer could receive if the EV tax credit gets repealed. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.
summary: Elon Musk reaffirmed his commitment to Tesla, stating he plans to remain CEO for the next five years, which analysts believe is crucial given Tesla's innovative nature beyond just being an auto company. The company is also launching a Robo Taxi beta program and aims to gain a profitability advantage over competitors like Waymo by using a cheaper camera-based system instead of lidar. However, the potential repeal of EV tax credits poses a risk, as it could negatively impact overall EV demand and Tesla's profit margins until Robo Taxis become a significant revenue source.

headline: Retail earnings ahead, Nvidia CEO on U.S. chip controls - what’s moving markets
description: Investing.com - U.S. stock futures dropped on Wednesday, after an uptick in Treasury yields weighed on stocks in the previous session. Markets are looking ahead to fresh retail earnings, with investors keen for any insight into the impact of President Donald Trump’s punishing tariffs on prices. Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang comments on U.S. curbs on artificial intelligence chip exports to China, while inflation in the U.K. surges.
summary: U.S. stock futures declined due to rising Treasury yields, as investors await retail earnings reports for insights into the impact of tariffs. Nvidia's CEO commented that U.S. export controls on AI chips to China have backfired, stimulating local development. Markets are also monitoring surging inflation in the U.K.

headline: What Trump could do if he's serious about trying to make companies 'eat' tariff price hikes
description: President Trump has taken aim at at least four retailers in recent weeks over possible tariff price hikes. He has an array of tools if he decides to escalate further.
summary: President Trump is publicly pressuring retailers like Walmart and Amazon to absorb potential tariff costs rather than passing them on to consumers. He has hinted at using various measures beyond mere observation, including potential investigations and even price controls, raising concerns about increased government intervention in business pricing. While unlikely to implement measures as extreme as price controls, Trump's actions reflect a growing bipartisan trend of government willingness to influence business pricing decisions.

headline: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq seesaw as bond sell-off eases after House OKs Trump tax bill
description: Investors worried about the US debt pile are weighing the House vote to approve President Trump's "big, beautiful" tax bill.
summary: US stocks showed little movement Thursday as investors considered the House's approval of Trump's tax bill and its potential impact on the national debt, highlighted by a recent Moody's credit rating downgrade. Bond yields eased after rising recently, while Bitcoin hit record highs amid increasing institutional demand. Economic data showed a rebound in May, though jobless claims indicated a potential softening in the labor market.

headline: Nvidia, Tesla lead over $250 billion in short-seller losses during massive market rally
description: Investors betting against stocks have lost more than $250 billion during the market's trade-induced rally.
summary: Short sellers have suffered significant losses, exceeding $250 billion, during the recent market rally as US stocks rebounded sharply. Tech giants like Nvidia and Tesla were major contributors to these losses, alongside other popular retail stocks experiencing short squeezes. Analysts suggest that short covering, rather than strong fundamentals, may have fueled the rally, with the market now awaiting economic data to determine future direction.

headline: Walmart joins layoff wave amid economic and global strains
description: Walmart (WMT) is cutting about 1,500 jobs to streamline operations across tech, e-commerce, and its ad business. Market Domination host Madison Mills breaks down how Walmart, TD Bank (TD) , Microsoft (MSFT), and Nissan (7201.T) are all turning to layoffs amid economic pressure and rising geopolitical uncertainty. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.
summary: Walmart is laying off approximately 1,500 employees to streamline its tech, e-commerce, and advertising divisions. This move is part of a broader trend of companies like TD Bank, Microsoft, and Nissan implementing layoffs in response to economic pressures and geopolitical uncertainty. The article suggests readers check out Market Domination for further market analysis.

headline: Nvidia stock poised to swing more than 7% as crucial earnings report will test the market rally
description: Options traders expect Nvidia stock to gain or lose as much as 7.4% the day after the AI chipmaker reports quarterly earnings results May 28 — a metric called “options implied volatility.”
summary: Options traders predict Nvidia's stock price will fluctuate by up to 7.4% the day after its earnings report on May 28, a smaller swing than the average volatility seen in recent quarters. While past earnings reports have led to volatile trading days, long-term investors have historically seen significant gains from holding Nvidia stock. Recent factors impacting Nvidia's stock include AI competition, trade policies, and overseas expansion opportunities.

headline: Nvidia, Tesla lead over $250 billion in short-seller losses during massive market rally
description: Investors betting against stocks have lost more than $250 billion during the market's trade-induced rally.
summary: Short sellers have suffered significant losses, exceeding $250 billion, as the US stock market rebounded strongly since April 8. This rally, fueled by factors like easing trade restrictions and renewed company focus, has particularly squeezed shorts in tech giants like Nvidia and Tesla, as well as popular retail trading names. Analysts suggest that short covering contributed to the market rally, which may not solely reflect strong underlying fundamentals.

headline: Nvidia, Tesla lead over $250 billion in short-seller losses during massive market rally
description: Investors betting against stocks have lost more than $250 billion during the market's trade-induced rally.
summary: Short sellers have suffered significant losses, exceeding $250 billion, as the stock market rebounded sharply, particularly impacting tech giants like Nvidia and Tesla. This "short squeeze" extended beyond large-cap tech, with popular retail trading names also experiencing substantial gains, further squeezing short positions. Analysts suggest that short covering contributed to the rally as market participants had turned bearish, and future market performance will depend on economic data.
